dt: {bc}a watery solution that circulates through a plant's vascular system
{bc}a body fluid (such as blood) essential to life, health, or vigor

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}sæp{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}saf{/it} sap
shortdef: the fluid part of a plant; specifically : a watery solution that circulates through a plant's vascular system
a body fluid (such as blood) essential to life, health, or vigor
to drain or deprive of sap
to knock out with a sap

dt: {bc}to subvert by digging or eroding the substratum or foundation {bc}{sx|undermine||}
{bc}to gradually diminish the supply or intensity of
{bc}to weaken or exhaust the energy or vitality of

dt.t: the illness {it}sapped{/it} him of his stamina

dt: {bc}to operate against or pierce by a sap

pt: {sc}weaken{/sc} {sc}enfeeble{/sc} {sc}debilitate{/sc} {sc}undermine{/sc} {sc}sap{/sc} {sc}cripple{/sc} {sc}disable{/sc} mean to lose or cause to lose strength or vigor. {sc}weaken{/sc} may imply loss of physical strength, health, soundness, or stability or of quality, intensity, or effective power.

pt.t: a disease that {it}weakens{/it} the body's defenses

pt: {sc}enfeeble{/sc} implies a condition of marked weakness and helplessness.
{sc}debilitate{/sc} suggests a less marked or more temporary impairment of strength or vitality.
{sc}undermine{/sc} and {sc}sap{/sc} suggest a weakening by something working surreptitiously and insidiously.

pt.t: drugs had {it}sapped{/it} his ability to think

pt: {sc}cripple{/sc} implies causing a serious loss of functioning power through damaging or removing an essential part or element.
{sc}disable{/sc} suggests bringing about impairment or limitation in a physical or mental ability.

pt.t: {it}disabled{/it} by an injury sustained at work

et: Middle French {it}sapper{/it}, from Old Italian {it}zappare{/it}, from {it}zappa{/it} hoe
shortdef: to proceed by digging a sap
to subvert by digging or eroding the substratum or foundation : undermine
to gradually diminish the supply or intensity of

dt: {bc}the extension of a trench to a point beneath an enemy's fortifications

shortdef: the extension of a trench to a point beneath an enemy's fortifications

dt: {bc}the liquid contents of a plant cell vacuole

shortdef: the liquid contents of a plant cell vacuole

dt: {bc}the clear homogeneous ground substance of a cell nucleus

shortdef: the clear homogeneous ground substance of a cell nucleus

dt: used to indicate that something left unsaid may or should be inferred

et: short for New Latin {it}verbum sapientī{/it} ({it}sat est{/it}) "a word to the wise (is sufficient)," after Latin {it}dictum sapientī sat est{/it} (Plautus)
shortdef: enough said —used to indicate that something left unsaid may or should be inferred

dt: lake 87 miles (140 kilometers) long in western Cambodia
